Kent Beck wrote:
> Neil,
>
> Thank you for the example. Would it be sufficient to make
> invokeTestMethod(Method method) protected so you could subclass
> TestClassRunner?
>
>
>> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
>> Behalf Of Neil Swingler
>>
>> decorating a test class TestSuite in JUnit3 but does not offer a
>> solution to decorating the individual test methods.
>>
>> Lets say I code a custom Runner to run each test in it's own
>> classloader
>> but otherwise I want all the other standard JUnit4 annotations to be
>> respected. I can reuse the TestIntrospector and
>> TestMethodRunner classes
>> (although they are in an internal package). But there is
>> still code in
>> TestClassRunner to do with exception handling that I will
>> have to duplicate.
>>
>>
Hi Kent, I have made invokeTestMethod protected in my version of junit.
It enables me to introduce the classloader. Here is my code:

public class ReloadingTestClassRunner extends TestClassRunner {
private TestNotifier notifier;
private Class<?> testClass;

public void initialize(TestNotifier notifier,
Class<? extends Object> testClass) {
super.initialize(notifier, testClass);
this.notifier = notifier;
this.testClass = testClass;
}

protected void invokeTestMethod(Method method) throws Exception {
ClassReloader classReloader = new ClassReloader(
(URLClassLoader) testClass
.getClassLoader());
Class<?> reloadedClass = classReloader
.reload(testClass);
Method reloadedMethod = reloadedClass.getMethod(method
.getName(), (Class[]) method
.getParameterTypes());
new TestMethodRunner(reloadedClass.newInstance(),
reloadedMethod, this.notifier).run();
}
}

- Neil
